facts.text: Appeal from an order of the High Court of Patna dated 9th September 1948 by Agarwala C.J. and Meredith J. in J.C. No. 5 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 61 of 1950. Appeal from an order of the High Court of Patna dated 9th September, 1948,  Agarwala C.J. and Meredith J.  in J.C. No. 5 of 1948.

facts.text: The appeal was originally filed as Federal Court Appeal No. 71 of 1948 on a certificate granted by the Patna High Court under cl. 31 of the Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was originally filed as Federal Court Appeal No. 71 of 1948 on a certificate granted by the Patna High Court under cl. 31 of the Letters Patent of that High Court that the case was a fit one for appeal to the Federal Court.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZL ALI J. on 1950 November 30.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. November 30. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by FAzL ALl J. FAZL ALI J. --This is an appeal from an order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna dated the 9th September, 1948, declining to call upon the board of Revenue to state a case under section 21  3  of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944  Act VI of 1944 , with reference to an assessment made under that Act.

facts.text: High Court of Patna dated 9th September 1948 declining to call upon the board of Revenue to state a case under section 21(3) of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1944 with reference to an assessment.

anchor.surface_text: FAZL ALI J. --This is an appeal from an order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna dated the 9th September, 1948, declining to call upon the board of Revenue to state a case under section 21  3  of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944  Act VI of 1944 , with reference to an assessment made under that Act.

facts.text: Bihar Sales Tax Act was passed in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar Sales Tax Act was passed in 1944, and section 4 of the Act provides that every dealer whose gross turn- over during the year immediately preceding the companymencement of the Act exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax under the Act on sales effected after the date so numberified.

facts.text: Section 4 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1944 provides that every dealer whose gross turnover during the year immediately preceding the commencement of the Act exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax on sales after the notified date.

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar Sales Tax Act was passed in 1944, and section 4 of the Act provides that every dealer whose gross turn- over during the year immediately preceding the companymencement of the Act exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax under the Act on sales effected after the date so numberified.

facts.text: Appellant has been doing contract work on a fairly extensive scale for the Central Public Works Department and the East Indian Railway.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that, having regard to the definitions of dealer, goods and sale under the Act, the appellant, who has been doing companytract work on a fairly extensive scale for the Central Public Works Department and the East Indian Railway, companyes within the category of a dealer mentioned in section

facts.text: Appellant comes within the category of a dealer mentioned in section 4 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that, having regard to the definitions of dealer, goods and sale under the Act, the appellant, who has been doing companytract work on a fairly extensive scale for the Central Public Works Department and the East Indian Railway, companyes within the category of a dealer mentioned in section Section 7 of the Act provides that numberdealer shall, while being liable under section 4 to pay tax under the Act, carry on business as a dealer unless he has been registered under the Act and possesses a registration certificate.

facts.text: Appellant filed an application for registration on 19th December 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Act provides that numberdealer shall, while being liable under section 4 to pay tax under the Act, carry on business as a dealer unless he has been registered under the Act and possesses a registration certificate. In pursuance of this provision, the appellant filed an applica- tion for registration on the 19th December, 1944, and a certificate of registration was issued to him on the 21st December, 1944.

facts.text: A certificate of registration was issued to the appellant on 21st December 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this provision, the appellant filed an applica- tion for registration on the 19th December, 1944, and a certificate of registration was issued to him on the 21st December, 1944.

facts.text: On 8th October 1945, the Sales Tax Officer issued a notice to the appellant asking him to produce his accounts on 10th November 1945 and to show cause why penalty exceeding one and a half times the amount should not be imposed under section 10(5).

anchor.surface_text: On the 8th October, 1945, the Sales Tax Officer issued a numberice to the appellant asking him to produce his accounts on 10th November, 1945, and to show cause why in addition to the tax to be finally assessed on him a penalty number exceeding one and a half times the amount should number be imposed on him under section 10  5  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant appeared before the Sales Tax Officer in response to the notice but obtained several adjournments till 16th March 1946 and ultimately failed to appear.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10  5 , under which the numberice purported to have been issued, runs thus-- If upon information which has companye into his posses- sion, the Commissioner is satisfied that any dealer has been liable to pay tax under this Act in respect of any period and has nevertheless wilfully failed to apply for registra- tion, the Commissioner shall, alter giving the dealer a reasonable opportunity of being heard, assess, to the best of his judgment, the amount of tax, if any, due from the dealer in respect of such period and all subsequent periods and the Commissioner may direct that the dealer shall pay, by way of, penalty, in addition to the amount so assessed, a sum number exceeding one and a half times that amount. The appellant appeared before the Sales Tax Officer in response to this numberice, but obtained several adjournments till 16th March, 1046, and ultimately failed to appear.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer assessed the appellant according to best judgment and ordered payment of Rs. 4,526-13-0 as tax and penalty of one and a half times under section 10(5).

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, he was assessed by the Sales Tax Officer, accord- ing to the best of his judgment, and was ordered to pay Rs. 4,526-13-0 as tax and a penalty amounting to one and a half times the amount assessed, under section 10  5  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to the Commissioner against the assessment and penalty; appeal dismissed on 6th June 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appealed to the Commissioner against the assessment and the penalty levied upon him, but his appeal was dismissed on the 6th June, 1946.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition for revision to Board of Revenue against Commissioner's order; dismissed on 28th May 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He then filed a peti- tion for revision to the Board of Revenue, against the order of the Commissioner, but it was dismissed on the 28th May, 1947.

facts.text: Appellant moved Board of Revenue to refer questions of law to High Court; rejected by Mr. N. Baksi on 4th December 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon moved the Board of Revenue to refer to the High Court certain questions of law arising out of is order of the 28th May, but Mr. N. Baksi, a Member of the Board, by his order of the 4th December, 1947, rejected the petition with the following observations - No case for review of my predecessors order made out. No reference necessary.

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court under section 21 Bihar Sales Tax Act against Board's refusal to refer.

anchor.surface_text: Section 21 of the Act provides that if the Board of Revenue refuses to make a reference to the High Court, the applicant may apply to the High Court against such refusal, and the High Court, if it is number satisfied that such refusal was justified, may require the Board of Revenue to state a case and refer it to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court directed case back to Board of Revenue for stating case or proper rejection order.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this section, the appellant made an application to the High Court praying that the Board of Revenue may be called upon to state a case and refer it to the High Court. Dealing with this application, the High Court pointed out that the Member of the Board had number been asked to review his predecessors order but only to state a case, and gave the following directions -- The ease must, therefore, go back to the Board of Revenue for a case to be stated or for a proper ,order rejecting the application to be passed.

facts.text: Board of Revenue reheard the matter, rejected application and refused to state case.

anchor.surface_text: The Board then reheard the matter and rejected the application of the appellant and refused to state a case and refer it to the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant's second application to High Court for requiring Board to state case was summarily rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter made an application to the High Court for requiring the Board of Revenue to state a case, but this application was summarily rejected.

facts.text: High Court granted leave to appeal to Federal Court following Lahore Full Bench decision.

anchor.surface_text: He then applied to the High Court for leave to appeal to the Federal Court, which the High Court granted, following the decision of a Full Bench of the Lahore High Court in Feroze Shah Kaka Khd v. Income-tax Commissioner, punjab and N.W.F.P., Lahore

facts.text: Preliminary objection raised by respondent's counsel that appeal is not competent.

anchor.surface_text: At the companymencement of the hearing of the appeal in this Court, a preliminary objection was raised by the learned companynsel for the respondent that this appeals was number companype- tent, and, on hearing both the parties, we are of the opin- ion that the objection is wellfounded.

facts.text: Court held the preliminary objection well-founded and appeal not competent.

anchor.surface_text: At the companymencement of the hearing of the appeal in this Court, a preliminary objection was raised by the learned companynsel for the respondent that this appeals was number companype- tent, and, on hearing both the parties, we are of the opin- ion that the objection is wellfounded.

facts.text: In Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa, Patna High Court held no appeal lies under cl.31 Letters Patent from order dismissing application under s.66(3) Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bihar and Orissa  1  it was held by a special Bench of the Patna High Court that numberappeal lay to His Majesty in Council under clause 31 of the Letters Patent of the Patna High Court, from an order of the High Court dismissing an application under section 66  3  of the Income-tax Act,  a provision similar to section 21 of the Act before us

facts.text: High Court order under s.21 Bihar Sales Tax Act is not a final order affecting rights of parties.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the order appealed against in this case, cannot be regarded as a final order, because it does number of its own force bind or affect the rights of the parties. All that the High Court is required to do under section 21 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act is to decide the question of law raised and send a companyy of its judgment to the Board of Revenue.
declining to call upon the board of Revenue to state a case under section 21  3  of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944  Act VI of 1944 , with reference to an assessment made under that Act.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 31 of the Letters Patent of the Patna High Court, on the strength of which the appellant resists the prelimi- nary objection raised by the respondent, runs thus -- And We do further ordain that any person or persons may appeal-to Us, Our heirs and successors, in Our or Their Privy Council, in any matter number being of criminal juris- diction, from any final judgment, decree, or order of the said High Court of Judicature at Patna, made on appeal and from any final judgment, decree on order made in the exercise of original jurisdiction by Judges of the said High Court or of any Division Court, from which an appeal does number lie to the said High Court under the provisions companytained in the 10th clause of these

arguments.claim: Appeal lies under clause 31 of the Letters Patent of the Patna High Court
arguments.court_reasoning: Order not final order and not passed in original or appellate jurisdiction

arguments.claim: No appeal lay under clause 31 Letters Patent from High Court order dismissing application under section 66(3) Income-tax Act similar to section 21 Bihar Sales Tax Act
The view expressed in Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir by Patna High Court special bench is correct
The order under appeal is not a final order because it does not of its own force bind or affect the rights of the parties

Under section 21 Bihar Sales Tax Act, High Court decides question of law and sends judgment to Board of Revenue which disposes of the case finally, so High Court order standing by itself does not affect rights
To attract clause 31 Letters Patent, order must be final and passed in exercise of original or appellate jurisdiction of High Court
The order was not passed by High Court in exercise of original or appellate jurisdiction
High Court order in such references is merely advisory or consultative, not a judgment or order affecting rights
View of Lahore Full Bench that such appeal justified as from original jurisdiction not supported by several other High Courts
Such appeal justified under clause 9 Letters Patent Lahore as final judgment in original jurisdiction by Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: following the decision of a Full Bench of the Lahore High Court in Feroze Shah ... The High Court pointed out in the order granting leave that in the appeal that was taken to the Privy Council in the Lahore case ... as being an appeal from a final judgment, decree or order made in the exercise of original jurisdiction by a Division Bench

arguments.court_reasoning: Preferred Patna HC view and distinguished Lahore

holdings.text: the objection [that the appeal is not competent] is wellfounded

anchor.surface_text: At the commencement of the hearing of the appeal in this Court, a preliminary objection was raised by the learned counsel for the respondent that this appeal was not competent, and, on hearing both the parties, we are of the opinion that the objection is wellfounded. holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court order under s.21 Bihar Sales Tax Act dismissing application is neither final order affecting parties' rights nor made in original/appellate jurisdiction required by cl.31 Letters Patent; follows Patna HC precedent on similar Income Tax provision

holdings.text: In our opinion, the view expressed in the Patna case is correct
holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses Patna High Court special bench holding that no appeal lies under cl.31 Letters Patent from order dismissing application under s.66(3) Income-tax Act (analogous to s.21 Bihar Sales Tax Act)

holdings.text: the order appealed against in this case, cannot be regarded as a final order, because it does not of its own force bind or affect the rights of the parties
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court under s.21 decides question of law and sends judgment to Board of Revenue, which disposes finally; High Court order alone does not bind/affect rights (citing Tata Iron & Steel and Lord Esher)

holdings.text: it is necessary to show, firstly, that the order under appeal is a final order and secondly, that it was passed in the exercise of the original or appellate jurisdiction of the High Court
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.31 Letters Patent requires both finality and original/appellate jurisdiction; s.21 proceedings are consultative/advisory, not original or appellate

holdings.text: It cannot also be held that the order was passed by the High Court in this case in the exercise of either original or appellate jurisdiction
holdings.reasoning_summary: No contention of appellate jurisdiction; s.21 reference jurisdiction is merely consultative, not original (citing Tata Iron & Steel Co. v. Chief Revenue Authority)
